volker 2.0.1.9000
  • Introduction
  • Reference
  • Changelog

Output effect size and test statistics for paired samples

Source: R/effects.R
effect_metrics_items.Rd

The correlation is calculated using stats::cor.test.

Usage

effect_metrics_items(
  data,
  cols,
  negative = FALSE,
  method = "pearson",
  labels = TRUE,
  clean = TRUE,
  ...
)

Arguments

data

A tibble containing item measures.

cols

The column holding metric values.

negative

If FALSE (default), negative values are recoded as missing values.

method

The output metrics, TRUE or pearson = Pearson's R, spearman = Spearman's rho.

labels

If TRUE (default) extracts labels from the attributes, see codebook.

clean

Prepare data by data_clean.

...

Placeholder to allow calling the method with unused parameters from effect_metrics.

Value

A volker table containing correlations.

Examples

library(volker)
data <- volker::chatgpt

effect_metrics_items(data, starts_with("cg_adoption"))
#> 
#>

#> |Using ChatGPT brings me recognition from my environment.    |               In my environment, using ChatGPT is standard.| 97|        0.57|   0.42|    0.69| 95|  6.85| 0.000|   ***|
#> |Using ChatGPT brings me recognition from my environment.    |             Almost everyone in my environment uses ChatGPT.| 97|        0.54|   0.38|    0.67| 95|  6.23| 0.000|   ***|
#> |Using ChatGPT brings me recognition from my environment.    |          Not using ChatGPT is considered being an outsider.| 97|        0.56|   0.40|    0.68| 95|  6.53| 0.000|   ***|

#> 4 missing case(s) ommited.
